summary: This 1980 compilation from the Review of Ghana Law reports on personal injury awards from 1978–1979, primarily arising from road accidents. The cases cover both fatal injuries and multiple injury claims, with awards determined by various High Court judges across Ghana. In fatal cases, compensation includes loss of dependency (calculated by years' purchase of income), loss of expectation of life, mental distress to dependants, and special damages for funeral expenses. For non-fatal injuries, awards factor in pain and suffering, permanent disability, disfigurement, loss of amenities, loss of future earnings, and special damages. Judicial reasoning reflects structured assessment of pecuniary and non-pecuniary losses, with adjustments for likelihood of remarriage, age, earning capacity, and extent of physical and psychological impairment. The data serves as a benchmark for personal injury valuations in Ghanaian civil litigation during the period.
verdict: Plaintiffs awarded varying sums for personal injury or loss of dependant, with compensation structured around loss of income, pain and suffering, and special damages.
citations: ADABO v. GHANA CONSOLIDATED DIAMONDS LTD. [1979]
rationaleHighlights: Awards based on years' purchase of income, scaled down for dependency
Loss of expectation of life separately assessed
Special damages include funeral costs and medical expenses
Permanent disability percentages used to calculate awards
Mental distress recognized for dependants in fatal cases
Disfigurement and loss of amenities factored into non-pecuniary damages
Child and elderly dependants considered in dependency calculations
Future health risks (e.g., epilepsy, arthritis) accounted for in awards
confidenceNotes: Data extracted from a compiled report of awards in personal injury cases; original judgments not reviewed. Amounts reflect pre-1980s Ghanaian cedi values.
